Description: Part of a green glazed composition tile: decorated with ribbed lines. The only edge to remain unbroken is covered with a blue glaze of a paler shade than the green of the ribbed face. The tile's upper side is convex, and it is pierced to facilitate its attachment to a wall.
Curator's comments: This tile was found in debris associated with the early Osiris Temple at Abydos, but has no specific context. It is interesting to note that, while the tile is green, the unbroken edge displays a light blue colour. Precisely what this tile decorated at Abydos is unknown because no tiles have been found in situ, but it is quite likely that the walls of the sanctuary and nearby shrines were decorated in the same manner as the niches of Djoser's funerary complex. For parallels, see W. M. F. Petrie, 'Abydos' I (London, 1902), pl. LIII, 20-2; W. M. F. Petrie, 'Abydos' II (London, 1902-4), pl. XI, 237; A. Scharff, ‘Die Altertümer der Vor – und Frühzeit Ägyptens’ (Berlin, 1929-31), no. 367 and pl. 38. Bibliography: W. M. F. Petrie, 'Abydos' I (London, 1902), pl. LIII, 19.
Bibliographic references: Friedman 1998 / Gifts of the Nile: Ancient Egyptian Faience (16)
